Maybe our "Erzählcafés" www.unibe.ch/ub/erzaehlcafes or "Workshops" www.unibe.ch/ub/workshops (both in german language) would also be interesting for your members? item.title: Carole Burkhalter - 2021-09-05 20:58:40
item.content:encoded: Hi, I'm a Bern local, but have been living and working in Ireland for the past 3 years. Now I'm back in Bern and I would love to meet new people from all over the world and keep practicing my English.. I'm 38 years old, work as a teacher in a vocational school and speak German, English and French. Kind regards, Carole <!--more--> AUTHOR: Carole Burkhalter AUTHOR EMAIL: c_burkhalter@gmx.ch AUTHOR URL: SUBJECT: [WP.com Block Patterns] Contact IP: 178.238.175.96 Array ( [1_Name] => Carole Burkhalter [2_Email] => c_burkhalter@gmx.ch [3_Message] => Hi, I'm a Bern local, but have been living and working in Ireland for the past 3 years. I'm 38 years old, work as a teacher in a vocational school and speak German, English and French. item.title: Andy Mering - 2021-11-13 15:33:38
item.content:encoded:
Hi Graham, I am Swiss, passionate about English, have recently earned my doctorate in English sociolinguistcs. I love to chat with people in English (via Zoom, for instance). It would be great if I could meet up with people and have a nice chat with them. Have a great weekend best wishes
Andy <!--more--> AUTHOR: Andy Mering AUTHOR EMAIL: andy.mering@bluewin.ch AUTHOR URL: SUBJECT: [WP.com Block Patterns] Contact IP: 85.7.162.149 Array ( [1_Name] => Andy Mering [2_Email] => andy.mering@bluewin.ch [3_Message] => Hi Graham, I am Swiss, passionate about English, have recently earned my doctorate in English sociolinguistcs. item.title: 2014.01.19 Canadian Brunch
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Each year, Canada Weeks are held at the Old Tram Depot. Members attend tourism presentations and a Sunday Brunch with live music.

I think this year we heard the Good Brothers https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Good_Brothers

item.title: About the ICB
item.dc:creator: ausfrog
item.content:encoded:
The International Club of Bern (ICB) was founded in 1991: a non-political association open to all people who are interested in meeting others for social, sporting and cultural activities. We have activities exploring all aspects of life in Switzerland.

Note : Bern is the German and English name for the city, Berne is the French name, and Berna is the Italian and Romansh name.

Find out about what the Club offers, click the Activities page. To see the current programme, click the Calendar page.

We have members from all over the world. Our common language is English. The club currently has members from over 30 countries and six continents. Some are born Swiss or naturalized Swiss citizens. 

We welcome all new members for the opportunity to meet and make new friends. Our newsletter is published every two months provides information of events and activities. If you have any questions, do not hesitate to contact us.

The statutes of the club are in the By-Laws. Our General Meetings are conducted according to Roberts Rules, as simply as possible. A more comlex guideline is here.

item.dc:creator: ausfrog
item.content:encoded:
How to join the Club

Give us your postal address using the Contact form or your email addresse and we will send you a Newsletter.

Accessing this website and its blog does not mean joining the Club.

Membership:is open to anyone but is more useful to those living in Berne or about to move there or its surroundings.

Yearly fees: CHF 50 (membership for a single membership and CHF 60 (for a family). 

Club postal address:
International Club of Berne
3000 Bern.

The Club Account

PostFinance account inumber: 30-106-9.
IBAN number : CH95 0079 0042 3449 8516 7.

Please specify ICB and your name on the payment.

Please download and complete the Membership Application Form. You can also complete the Interest Form so we can be aware about your special interests.

We look forward to meeting you.

item.title: Activities
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
We have Special interest groups. Click on any of the links to go to postings in our blog. Ask about WhatsApp chats.

Languages: There are meetings of our conversation cafés once or twice a month for anyone who is learning or who wants to practice speaking another language, though these cafés are not courses. Native speakers are welcome, with everyone helping each other.

French / German / Swiss-German / English / Arabic / Turkish / Spanish / Italian / Portuguese / Russian

Special Interest Groups: for those who want to share their passions with others.

Museums: including fine art, architecture and history
Musical culture: classical, opera, theater, jazz, ...
Botanical Gardens, gardens and nature
Handcrafts - painting, sketching, crafts, ...
Singing, writing, poetry.

Age-related groups: Parents and children, parents with teenagers / Ladies / Seniors

Get-togethers: we have a monthly TGIF (Thank Goodness It's Friday) for drinks or dining, and in Corona time, get-togethers for chatting or parties using Zoom or Skype or Google Meet. Our tasting events include wines, spirits, teas, cheeses, cigars or anything else you can think of! Also Dining and sometimes Cooking groups

Sports Activities of many kinds:

Hikes (= longer walks in the countryside)
Walks (= shorter city tours and visits)
Swimming and Picnics at pools, rivers and lakes
Cycling (city, country or mountain biking)
Climbing (in a hall or in the mountains)
Fitness, yoga and dancing of many varieties
Winter Sports: Skiing / Skating / Spas
Racket sports: Squash / Tennis / Badminton

Discussions: We have monthly Club Meetings on Tuesday evenings with invited speakers. In Corona time we have weekly Zoom meetings on Monday evening with general or specific topics, like these:

Communication and Health / Future Earth / Economics and Politics / Corona
Life-Long Learning / sciences

Books: We have many options for book readers in general. We discuss a new story or book each month, using several "breakout" chat groups

Sophie Reading Group - the group for all readers
Special groups for genres: SciFi, Crime & Spy
Also short stories, non-fiction, biographies
Special groups for regions: British Books / Americana / Oriental / Africa / Swiss and German / Oceania

item.title: About the Club
item.dc:creator: ausfrog
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

  • The International Club of Berne was founded in 1991 as a non-political association open to all residents of Berne and surroundings who are interested in meeting for social and cultural activities.
  • Find out more about the club's history on the About page.
  • Find out what we offer on the Activities page.
  • Currently we don't put the Calendar online. Ask to receive the Newsletter.

Who can join and how

  • People from all over the world are welcome. The common language is English although many other languages are spoken.
  • Around half of our members are Swiss, often with a dual citizenship.
  • To become a member, see the Join page
  • Get in touch with us by post or email or send a message from the Contact page.

Communications

  • We keep in contact by different means in person or online using different media channels. Click on the Communications page.
  • We post about events on our Blog.

item.title: Communications
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
• ICB Executive Committee and activity leaders are listed a printed Newsletter.
  • The Newsletter is our main communication medium. A paper version is sent by post and a digital version by email every two months.
    • Forum: we are looking into developing forums for the exchange of ideas.
    • Photos: We maintain an archive of pictures from various events
    • News: We use emails for the latest club news, or find News on the blog
  • Blog at icberne.org/blog/
    To post or comment, you will need a WordPress account and authorization
  • Facebook page is at www.facebook.com/groups/icberne 
  • WhatsApp is for special interest groups and discussions.
  • We can also meet online using Zoom.

item.title: 2013.01.20 Malaysian Cooking

item.title: Contact the ICB
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Let us know your postal address we will send you our latest Newsletter. Give it a try: take part in our activities and meet our members. In a month or two we will ask you if you wish to join the Club.

Suggestions for activities are always welcome. Tell us what interests you!

Chat on WhatsApp

PLease Mail US

Postfach
3000 Bern

contact@icberne.org

item.title: Chats
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
We have many special interest groups which share their information using WhatsApp chats and google groups. Click below to go to linked lists of these groups, and join the ones that interest you.

Some groups are open to anyone living near Berne, not just ICB members. We ask for your forename. Join the groups that interest you to find activities and to talk to others. Introduce yourself and take part when you feel like it. Be tolerant and observe conversational etiquette. Mute the group if a discussion annoys you, and come back when you find somehing interesting. If you leave the group, it's polite to say goodbye.

Lists of chat groups

  • General Interest Groups: for conversation with other members and events like brunch, TGIF, and discussion meetings
  • Language and Cultural Groups: take part in the monthly language cafes, online conversations and Zoom meetings
  • Sports Groups: join or find out about sporting activities
  • Special Interest Groups: join whichever group interests you
  • Literary groups: novels and short stories, in many genres
  • Discussion groups: health, politics, sustainability, corona, general

Joining activities

See the Calendar in the ICB Newsletter or on the Website for dates and times of activities. Contact the leader if you are interested in taking part. You can also register on the appropriate chat group.

We have both online (zoom) and in-person (real-life) activities.

See the Blog for past activities and events.

item.title: Newsletters
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
The ICB Newsletter is the main communication channel for the club. It is a paper document (remember that old stuff?).

We send it to members and some organisations in Berne. We send it to "prospective members", those who have told us they are interested in the club and have given us their email and postal addresses. We do this for just two or three editions, enough time for them to become interested in the club and attend activities and make a decision to join the club or not.

If you are interested in joining the club, check the page here.

Some of our old Newsletters can be found in blog posts.

item.title: 2012.11.13 Tasting - Gourmet group
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
We have started new activities in the club, which will appeal to a lot of us. The general term is tasting - because we do not consider ourselves generally as gourmets or experts, but just people who like sensations!

On 13 November, 2012, we had a wine-tasting evening at the Cheminee meeting room of the Bruder Klaus church, our usual club meeting place. Each person brought a bottle of wine from their native country. It was a lot of fun, 14 members attended.

On 27 December we had a wine-tasting at the lovely home of Lois and Mark. The theme was blended red wines, and 13 attended.

On 25 January 2013 we meet at Salvey's wine cellar at 1800, www.salvey.ch to sample their wares. There is a fee of 10.- for the evening. Note that afterwards in the cellar below, there is country line dancing in the Honky Tonk saloon.

Ideas for the future include chocolate tasting or a visit to a chocolate factory, a visit to Vom Fass http://www.vomfass-bern.ch/, cheese tasting, beer and / whisky sampling, ... what would YOU like?  Here is an article about coffee tasting: http://www.streetdirectory.com/food_editorials/beverages/coffee/gourmet_coffee_tastes_defined.html

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: We had a further wine tasting event at the "club room" in the Bruder Klaus church. There wer twelve attendees including new member Carolina Sauviron and Sheila from Chester in England who brought delicious brownies. We had lots of snacks including cheese, cashews, flutes, biscuites, savouries, humus, tasty and plain bread. The theme was South American wines, we had a lot from Chile and Argentina. Personally I was not impressed by most of them, hard on my throat, the whites were the best. We had general approval for a wine tasting each 2 or 3 months, interspersed with whiskey, cheeses, tea, whatever. (Everybody brings 6 teabags, should be a cheap evening :) I hope we can combine in May and June with www.englishclub.ch for Mark Chesterfield of http://www.thewhiskyexperience.com/ and Michael Jones of http://www.cheeseclub.ch/ British cheese. A great suggestion for the summer was tastings at the Rose Gardens! Graham

item.title: 2013.02.11 Tea-Tasting
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
I found a great place today for tea tasting! Länggassetee.
www.laenggasstee.ch

TeeRaum (TeeRoom) on the first floor of our shop. This is the perfect place to try our teas in a quiet and relaxed atmosphere. This place can be used for tea nights, tea courses, tea ceremonies and other events.

We can have an English High Tea (which includes a lot to eat for 35.- per person!) High tea

We offer a wonderful breakfast buffet every Saturday morning from 09.00 to 12.00 for 25.- buffet

You can accomplish one or more degustations any time. A degustation means drinking tea in a comparative way. Either you get to know different kinds of treatments of the tea plant (white, green, brown, black etc) or you discover a certain variety in its diversity (e.g. different Darjeelings from different gardens). We are glad to advise you. Price per set of four teas CHF 12.00

You can have a traditional Japanese Tea Ceremony in our special rooms. Price 60 pp. Japanese

You can have a Chinese tea ceremony for 16.- Chinese

There is a matinee each Saturday von 10-12 im Raritätenladen (Anmeldung nicht erforderlich) matinee

Katrin, Gerhard, Kaspar, Lukas, Moritz & Sebastian Lange & colleagues
Länggass-Tee
Familie Lange AG
Länggassstrasse 47 3012 Bern Switzerland
info@laenggasstee.ch

item.title: 20130412 Wine-Tasting
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
14 attendees from 14 countries enjoyed the event organised by Lois at the English-speaking club.

We discussed future tastings ... here are some locations all in Länggasse
- tea at www.laenggasstee.ch
- ice-cream at www.gelateriadiberna.ch
- coffee and beer at www.caffebarsattler.ch
- coffee and bagels at www.tingel-kringel.ch

The story of Gelateria di Berna
http://www.bernerzeitung.ch/region/bern/ItaloGlace-aus-der-Laenggasse/story/17068336

We had even more ideas
- Whiskeys and liquors at www.vomfass-bern.ch
- Ten varieties of mineral water in the summer at Marzili
- Coffee at the Nespresso factory in Avenches
http://www.nestle-nespresso.com/newsandfeatures/nespresso-completes-expansion-of-its-avenches-production-and-distribution-centre-
http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/index.html?cid=67936

We would like to have some summer trips
France: Beaune for beaujolais and Dijon for mustard
Italy: outlet shopping, local products, and markets in Ticino
Germany: fashion shopping in Mettingen, products from the Black Forest
These could be Saturday-Sunday trips with one overnight stay.

It depends on people to propose and organise these - possibly on the forum "trips"

I look forward to more activity!
Graham

item.title: 2014.02.22 - Hungarian Evening
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
These are the wines which we tasted at the Hungarian Wine Evening of 22 February. Many thanks to our host Gabor Meszaros.

White wines

 Táltoshegyi Olaszrizling 2006

Olaszrizling (Welschriesling) is the most common white grape in Hungary. The location is north from Balaton, Káli-medence (Kál basin), known from volcanic soil, giving minerality to the wines. The winemaker is Sándot Tóth, www.schellerbor.hu.

Tokaji Furmint 2011

Furmint is one of the two most important autochton (own) white grapes in Hungary. It is considered to be suitable to show the teroir. Tokaj is known mainly for sweet wines. Recently winemakers are seeking the ways for the dry Tokaj wine. The cellar Kikelet is a small familz enterprise. Stephanie, a French winemaker lady fell in love with Tokaj and a winemaker, Zsolt in Tokaj, they are producing special wines there. www.tokajkikelet.hu

Somlói Juhfark 2012

Juhfark is a rare Hungarian grape type, nearly extincted during the communism. Somló being a single hill North from Balaton is the smalles but one of the most special wine districts of the world. Vulcanic soil, wich gives extreme minerality, a unmistakable terroir. The producer, Károly Kolonits has a small family cellar. www.kolonicspinceszet.hu/

Somlói Hárslevelű 2009, Somlói Apátsági Pince

Hárslevelű (Lindenblätter) is the other important autochton grape type in Hungary, with special nose. The producer works on 3.5ha, and they make the wine in a cellar that used to belong to the Pannonhalma Abbey. They make natural, no compromise wines. www.juhfark.hu

Red wines

Szekszádri Kadarka 2011

Kadarka used to be the most important red grape in Hungary. Now it is rare because it is sensitiv and needs special care. It gives elegant wines, sometimes referred to as „puszta-Pinot” (with a little irony). Szekszárd is in South-Hungary close to Danube, known from red wines. The producer is Csaba Sebestyén, sebestyen-szekszard.hu.

Szekszárdi Cabernet Franc 2009

From the Boreaux grape types Cabernet Franc looks to fit to best to the Hungarian climat. The producer is Gábor Vida,

Egri Kékfrankos, 2011, Orsolya Pince, Eger

Kékfrankos (Blaurfänkisch) is the most important red wine now in Hungary. We argue with the Austrians about the origin of the grape. The cellar is a family company, producing natural wines, many climate selections, sometimes only in a few hundred bottles. www.orsolyapince.hu 

Sweet wine from Tokaj

Áts cuveé, Royal Tokaji, 2011

The cellar is the interest of the British wine expert, Hugh Johnson. The winemaker is Károly Áts. This is a simple, non-traditional late harvest wine. www.royal-tokaji.com

Tokaji Aszú 5p 2004, Zemplén Hegyhát

Aszú is the sweet wine where the botrytised berries are collected one-by-one separatelly, and later dosed to the most or to the wine. The ratio of wine and botrytised berries give the basis of the calssification (3p, 4p, 5p, 6p). At that time the most know Hungarian wine maker, István Szepsy still helped to the cellar.

Grappa

The grappas which we tasted were all the production of Gabor, these:

Furmint from Somló

Hárslevelű from Somló

Juhfark from Somló

Apricot

item.title: Ulrike, 2010
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
ICB, or the Beauty of Diversity

We are children of the universe
but adults of different nations
We share our different heritage

    we create a space to be
    we embrace diversity

We speak different languages
but feel encouraged to understand
We strengthen the other ones charisma

   we create a space to be
   we embrace diversity

We exercise tolerance
but we are not indifferent
We pay respect to different opinions

    we create a space to be
    we embrace diversity

We enjoy our gatherings in awareness
We take responsibility
and earn peace and friendship

item.title: Nazanin, 2015
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
In 1991, the founders of the International Club of Berne and its first committee members didn’t have a clue where the club would be in 25 years. And yet, here we are, still functioning, thanks to the commitment and energy of our volunteers and the support of our members.

From personal experience, I find that joining the International Club and becoming an active member on the committee was the best thing I could do to improve my social life in a new country. Not only have I found many good friends through the club, but the experience has also made me feel at home and glad to be living in Switzerland.

item.content:encoded: I am grateful. I have met people from different parts of the world, I could make some valuable contacts, and I have made good friends.

item.title: 2012.10.03 Cooking Group founded
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
This is a proposal for an interational cooking group to prepare dishes for the 2012 ICB Xmas Party. Very good ideas. It shows what great ideas people have. Thank you Oscar B (who is a professional cook).

I add some old forum posts to the new club blog to give readers an idea of the actgivigties of the club.

- Graham, 2021

Hi all,

 Thank you, Nedra, for launching the proposal. Thank you all for your comments and for considering our proposal.

 The cooking group met last week with a non-cooking (but eating!) meeting. We focused on deciding how we want to run the group, our interests and expectations, and next steps for the group.

 As none of us has real experience in cooking groups we decided to start simple and learn from mistakes. First decision was to do the first cooking experience with a small group (not more than 10 people) and at someone’s place. Angela and Oscar (N), great hosts!, offered (again) their home and Angela will be leading the first session: Italian food.

 As all the people that attended the first Meeting wanted to join the first cooking session, there are only two seats left. That means that probably some people that showed interest would not be able to join us that day, so we thought that we should prepare something “bigger” for the second meeting.

 Last Friday I realized that we have a nice group of motivated and generous people, ready to share their knowledge, willing to learn tips and new techniques and recipes and have fun. I am positive that the group is already a reality and has a lot of potential. We thought that it would be a good idea to do some sort of “marketing” of the group and encourage other ICB members to join us. Here is where the idea to do “something” at the Club Xmas party arose.

 The idea is that each of us prepares its share for the pot luck and, in addition, we all as “cooking group” prepare something extra for all the attendees. We were happy to assume the extra food just for fun and for the experience to cook for others (this will be our contribution in exchange for the use of the facilities)

 We have not yet discussed what we can prepare (as we are still waiting for your approval), but one possibility can be to prepare a variety of appetizers (“tapas” and “pinchos” style). We can prepare 10 to 12 different elaborated “tapas” so we have the chance to welcome a higher number of “cooks” and make a large production.

 At one point of the discussion, we considered the possibility to (later on, when we have enough experience as a group) open the group to “eaters” so we can cook in a professional kitchen, keep the costs down and open the activity on a regular basis to more ICB members. It will be, though, when we feel ready to provide good quality for a large group. “Tapas” (less difficult) would be a good starting point.

 Please, feel free to contact me if I can be of any help for making the decision.

 Thanks

 Oscar B

item.title: 2011.02.04 BGM 2011
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
The Flyer and the Minutes

Minutes of the BGM (distributed by Irene in RTF format, thanks)

INTERNATIONAL CLUB OF BERNE

Biennial General Meeting, 4 February 2011

Restaurant Maygut, Wabern

Members present: 29
Apologies: Anna and Colin Farmer, Patricia and Hans Weyermann

Committee:
Graham Tritt, President
Werner Dettwiler, Vice-President
Gerd Ulbers, Treasurer
Nazanin Kupferschmid, Activities Chairperson
Irene Schenker, Secretary (minutes)

We started a little late, at 18.45h, as the restaurant had not prepared tables for the apero at the prearranged time. Graham Tritt welcomed all members and thanked them for their attending the BGM.

1) Minutes
The minutes of the previous BGM on 6 February 2009 were approved without objection.

2) Membership Report
Werner Dettwiler reported that over the past 5 years we had had almost the same number of members by the end of December (171 - 193) and that he is happy how things are going. However, we will have to think about getting more young people. He presented statistics showing the nationalities of our members and noted that quite a lot of us have more than one nationality. He invited attendees to let him know about
their preferences for events and activities.

3) Report from the Treasurer
Gerd Ulbers reported that he was happy to have positive news since our financial situation is very good. He pointed out that the club's income mainly results from the membership fees. We had very little income from advertisments. He regrets the lack of engagement of many of our members. More ideas for organizing an event would make our club even more attracitve.

  1. Report from the Auditor
    Madeleine Kieffer informed about her checking the treasurer's reports. She had found the accounts complete and everything in order. She recommended discharge of the treasurer and thanked him for his good work. The attendees agreed with applause and thanks were given to Madeleine as well.
    One open question remained – whether we are liable to make a taxation report. Graham Tritt pointed out that we are a non-profit organisation. However, he will get information from a tax adviser to make sure that our club is not bound to pay taxes.

5) Activity Report
Nazanin Kupferschmid reported about some events which had been especially popular over the past two years, for instance the Bulgarian evening, factory visits, and the different parties. She thanked those who had assisted with past events, especially Katia Huber, Josephine Greiner, Stefan Rieder and others.

6) Report from the President
Graham Tritt especially alluded to our monthly club meetings. He very much regrets that not more members attend this event. For this reason, he will not invite external people as speakers but hopes to find members who are willing to present a topic. We would welcome new activities, such as a revival of the dinner group which was quite a success in former years. Dancing events have not been a great success lately.

Graham also pointed out that the English Club of Berne always welcomes our members, for instance at the monthly Singing event. His wish as president is to have more general members on the board.

Peter Liang thanked Graham very much for the excellent job he had done as President in the past two years. Attendees agreed with applause.

7) Elections
The members of the old board were subsequently released from their duties. There had not been any new nominations for the next board.

Graham Tritt, Werner Dettwiler and Gerd Ulbers had accepted to remain in their function. Graham nominated Maren Kuster for Activity Co-ordinator, together with Nazanin Kupferschmid. Maren accepted but requires support from all members. In particular, Flor Oberli will assist her.

Nazanin nominated Judy Chisholm for secretary, since Irene Schenker has now retired after five years. The committee was very happy when she accepted. Both Nazanin and Irene will assist her when needed.

8) The Evening
The official part of the meeting was then closed. We enjoyed a very good dinner which had been subsidized by the club with 20 francs for every member.

Many stayed for the music, some enjoyed dancing, and we had a pleasant finale to the Biennial General Meeting.

item.title: 2013.02.09 BGM 2013 in Arcadia
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Flyer including reports prepared for the meeting or given at the meeting.

Extracts from the BGM Notice

Activity report

Election of the Executive Committee for 2013–2014

We have received the following nominations for the Committee. Nominations remain open for all positions until the vote. We first vote for all Committee positions, without assigning roles. We then vote for the roles or portfolios.

President’s report

Overview, logistics, attendance

Membership, finances, activities, marketing

Change and growth, new activities

New website, media, marketing

Future actions, importance of participating, Bylaw changes

Clubrooms, motions, budget, contracts

Elections, marketing

Membership report

Countries and numbers

Overview of changes, procedures

Marketing

Erika will lead a subcommittee tasked with promoting the club and gaining new members. Her plan is to analyze members’ needs and wishes, carry out a SWOT analysis (strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats) and define a marketing strategy for the club. We will determine our focus, where future members can be found and how to reach them.

We will then create presentation material describing what the ICB offers, its activities and services – what does someone gain in becoming a member? We will evaluate the different methods of promoting the club, including information events, advertising and online media, and implement them.

All club members are invited to help by creating and leading great activities and telling people about us.

Motions

Motions may be proposed and seconded by any member, and will be discussed and voted upon. The procedures are defined in “Robert’s Rules” and copies of a summary are available. A simple majority of the attendees is needed to pass a motion.

Proposals for the further development of our club include an enlargement of the Executive Committee and establishment of a permanent club location. Having clubrooms would require more income for the initial setup and running costs. The budget on page 4 will be explained.

The current financial loss implies a fee rise of CHF 10 per year (from the current CHF 35 single or 45 family membership). The club’s financial position can subsidize clubrooms, while group activities should cover their own running costs..

The following motions have been proposed (and may be amended).

Action list from the Futures Workshop of February, 2012

This is a list of the tasks which had been agreed the previous year. The BGM reviewed the tasks with assigned responsible persons and target dates for actions. Six tasks had already been achieved.

item.title: Join - Test
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Give us your postal address(using the Contact form) so we can send you our Newsletters. Take part in our activities and meet us. After a while, we will ask you to decide if you will join the club.

Subscribing to this site with its blog is NOT joining the club. As many of our activities are open to all (including non-members), you should subscribe if you wish to be able to post or comment in the blog.

Membership is only open to people living in and around Berne (or moving here) who are able to take part in our activities. We also expect you to have a basic knowledge for everyday communication in English (even though our members generally speak one or more of the Swiss national languages, among others).

The yearly fees are CHF 50 (single) and CHF 60 (family).  Please ask us if you need a payment slip - we prefer bank transfers!  (For paying by postal payment slip, please add CHF 2.00, the PostFinance fee!).

The club postal address is simply this:
International Club of Berne
3000 Bern.

The PostFinance account is 30-106-9.
The IBAN number for paying fees is CH95 0079 0042 3449 8516 7. Please specify ICB and your name.

You may download and fill out the Membership Application Form or we can send it in paper form. We also have an optional Interest Form so that you can tell us more about yourself, so that we can recommend specific activities and contacts. Each person in a family or household membership should fill out one form.

We look forward to welcoming you.

item.title: David Gaal - 2022-08-30 15:54:28
item.content:encoded:

item.title: 2021.02.14 City Hills Walk
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded: A small group walked from the Old Tram Depot via Obstberg, Schönenberg and finally via the Schneggeli-Weggeli and picnicked at the Luft Station before returning on the Path of Remembrance to bus 10.

item.title: 2021.01.31 Walk Aare Bremgarten
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded: A small group walked along the river Aare at Bremgarten, through the famous tunnel, and up to the old church.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Walks along the river Aare are favourites of many people in Berne. In the general section on walking activities we will have some maps of route suggestions and attractions on the way

item.title: 2021.01.17 Aare Walk
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded: We found out how to give Filipe a bath with a fire warming Aare water. We walked upriver past the flamingos, boars, steinbocks, etc. Rather than continuing to the Auguet bridge and back downriver on the other side, we took the same way back. Finally snacks at the Dählhölzli Zoo Restaurant. About 10 pm 2.5 hours in all.

item.title: Café Español: only virtual meetings
item.dc:creator: iferre
item.content:encoded:
Hi there,

Since the bars, cafés and restaurants' lockdown seems it's going to finish by the end of March, we shall be able to meet in person again on Thursday, April 1st.

As usual, Café members are encouraged to let us know if they are going to join the meeting or not -it may be cancelled if none applies to! Non-members of any level of Spanish-knowledge are welcome as well.

To contact the group (all of us!), please email cafeespannol [at] googlegroups [dot] com.

To join the group, please contact me at ivan [at] icberne [dot] com.

¡Hasta pronto!

Ivan
item.excerpt:encoded: The Date is set for the next Spanish Café.

item.title: 2019.06.16 Ulmizberg
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded: Oscar Vernon Nazanin Andy Dave on a walk from Schliern up the Ulmizberg to the mountain on the top. Zarema was lost somewhere.

item.title: 2020.06.02 Lauterbrunnen
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded: Early morning walk with Miri from Lauterbrunnen to Wengen in the Bernese Oberland

item.title: 2020.06.07 Trummelbach
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded: Led by Mirica and very popular

item.title: 2021.02.28 Diemtigtal
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Skiing: Is anyone interested in skiing on Sunday 28? We are thinking of Wiriehorn or Grimmialp, both reasonable priced resorts. The Diemtigtal is almost the nearest Oberland ski resort location.

Keen skiers could leave by train at 0839 or whenever they wish by car and have a full day in the mountains. Walkers can take the train at 10:39 or car and meet at Grimmiapl at 12:05.

Grimmialp is a gentle ski resort where I often took my children. You can get half-day passes, all 3 lifts are running, snowshoe and cross country trails open. Or better a ten trip card for Fr.60, I believe you can share this.

Without taking a lift pass, you can sled or cross country in the valley

http://www.grimmialp.ch/index.php/menu-winterbetrieb

They say all 3 lifts are running, the first being the short lift on the lower slope pictured here. Skiers take the chair lift up, at the top station there is a restaurant but you are not allowed to sit down :-( .

Just 5 of the 8 pistes are open, you probably cannot ski back to the bottom, it will be icy, and so take the chairlift back down. The two sled runs are open, as are 4 of the 6 cross-country trails. All 5 walks are open, and 3 restaurants for takeaway.
https://infosnow.ch/portal/?lang=de&saison=1&p=256&q=

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Yes weather looks great. Contact me if you are interested in skiing, even for learners.

From Tanja: graham, you wrote about skiing in grimmialp. i was there yesterday for snowshoe walking. the skiresort is quite low and it has been very warm this week. they were open but as far as i could tell the snow really wasn't great, very wet. you might want to look for a higher resort. just an input 😊
From Graham: Yes, that is what I want to check with the Webcam today. Thanks for the input. The resort is low, 1230m, *but skiiers will go up the chair lift up the mountain (height 1720m).
From Tanja: no, i'm not quite sure, that the chair lift wason, i just saw the bügellift running. but i didn't pay much attention
From Graham: They say all 3 lifts are running, so skiers take the chair lift up to Stiereberg (1830m) . Just 5 of the 8 pistes are open, you probably cannot ski back to the bottom, it will be icy, and so take the chairlift back down. The two sled runs are open, as are 4 of the 6 cross-country trails. All 5 walks are open, and 3 restaurants for takeaway.
https://www.infosnow.ch/~apgmontagne/?tab=web2&xid=256&saison=1

Here is the live WebCam for Grimmialp, at the bottom. There are only a few kids going up and down on the short T-bar
https://www.bergfex.ch/grimmialp/webcams/c15042/
Add the top station, it’s really foggy, it’s in the cloud, and there are hardly anybody there

item.title: 2015.02.14 The ICB Ball
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Until 2015 the Club held an annual Ball, in earlier years supported by a Tombola and raising funds for a charity cause. Due to rising costs we have not recently held such an event, but instead we have three or four times a year Parties which are very well liked and attended.

In 2015 we held the Ball at the Schweizerhof hotel with a lot of great dining and dancing.

item.title: 2015.08.12 Glacier 3000 Hike
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Siy members visited the glacier and the swing bridge of Glacier 3000 near Col du Pillon and Gstaad. See www.glacier3000.ch for more information.

Photos mostly taken by Gary.

https://www.glacier3000.ch/en

item.title: 2021.03.01 Zoom Meeting on Economics
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Spanish Café
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
We have a monthly event, Café Español, led by Ivan, usually on the first Thursday at 14:30. Physically in the Café Littéraire, Stauffacher’s Bookshop, Neuengasse 25-37, or virtually meeting on Zoom.

Join the Google group to get the latest information.

Hola a todos,

Como durante un tiempo no podremos vernos en persona, quizá sería una buena idea tener algún tipo de comunicación a distancia.

Podemos usar este grupo de correo para explicarnos cosas o compartir algún artículo interesante que hayamos encontrado por internet, por ejemplo.

También, si estáis interesados, podemos probar a reunirnos por videoconferencia. Hay un programa gratuito llamado Zoom (descarga desde https://www.zoom.us/) que nos permitiría hacerlo.

Comentad qué os parece, o si tenéis alguna otra idea.

Saludos cordiales y cuidaos mucho.
Ivan

item.title: Café Français
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Le café français est une activité du International Club of Berne.


Connaissez-vous des personnes francophones qui seraient intéressées par notre café ? Vous pouvez leur transmettre mon adresse e-mail ou les emmener au café. Si vous avez des idées / souhaits, n´hésitez pas à les dire. Lors du Café, vous pouvez toujours posez des questions de vocabulaire, de grammaire, etc. Si vous avez des difficultés de comprendre quelqu’un parce que la personne ne parle pas assez fortement ou s’il y a trop de bruit, merci de le signaler.

Join the WhatsApp chat group www.tinyurl.com/Berne-aide-en-francais

Visited a film in 2019
at 11:25am on Monday, 12th August 2019 https://www.rexbern.ch/programmreihe/special-nino-rota/
Fri 16 August LA STRADA https://www.rexbern.ch/filme/la-strada/ Mon 26 August PROVA D'ORCHESTRA https://www.rexbern.ch/filme/prova-dorchestra/
-------------------------------
Der grosse italienische Komponist Nino Rota (1911–1979) schrieb nicht weniger als 150 Filmmusiken. Legendär ist seine Musik für Coppolas Godfather, bekannt ist er vor allem für seine Kompositionen, die er für Federico Fellini (1920–1993) geschrieben hat. Von 1952 bis zu Rotas Tod arbeiteten die beiden eng zusammen; Rota unterwarf seine Ideen dabei vollständig den Ausdrucks- und Stimmungsbedürfnissen des Regisseurs. Dennoch gelang es ihm, eigenständige Melodien und Themen zu entwickeln, die er mehrfach in anderen Kontexten weiterverwertete.
Der Oratorienchor Bern gibt am 13. September ein Konzert mit Werken von Rota und bringt dabei nebst geistlichen Werken auch Filmmelodien aus La strada und La dolce vita von Fellini zur Aufführung. Wir zeigen im August diese beiden Filme, und dies nicht nur als Vorspiel zum Konzert des Oratorienchors, sondern auch zu unserer Fellini-Retrospektive, die wir für Dezember 2019 und Januar 2020 anlässlich des 100. Geburtstages von Fellini plan
------------------------------- La Strada Italien, 1954, 102 min, Digital HD, I/d, Regie: Federico Fellini, Drehbuch: Federico Fellini, Tullio Pinelli, mit: Anthony Quinn, Giuglietta Masina, Richard Basehart, Marcella Rovere, Aldo Silvani.
Der virile und gewalttätige Jahrmarktsartist Zampano kauft das einfältige Dorfmädchen Gelsomina, um es zu seiner Assistentin und Sklavin abzurichten. Gelsomina unterwirft sich seinen unwirschen Befehlen, aber den seiltanzenden Narren Matto, der sie menschlich behandelt, betet sie an. Zampano tötet Matto im Streit und verlässt Gelsomina, weil er jede menschliche Bindung als Last empfindet. Erst als er später von ihrem Tod hört, lässt ein hemmungsloser Gefühlsausbruch ahnen, was er für sie empfunden hat. Mit der poetisch-bizarren Tragödie entfernte sich Fellini erstmals vom Neorealismus.
«Liebe, Hass, Eifersucht, Angst, Gier, Machtgelüste und Mord – in Fellinis Film sind die Menschen beherrscht von ihren ungezügelten Urtrieben. Man sieht sie auf der Leinwand und hört sie in der Filmpartitur von Nino Rota, der die starken Gefühle in kraftvolle Rhythmen und Melodien verwandelt hat. Eine Trompetenmelodie zieht sich dabei wie ein Leitmotiv durch die Partitur: die Melodie, die der Seiltänzer dem Mädchen auf einer Spielzeugtrompete beigebracht hat.» SWR2
-------------------------------
Prova d’orchestra 18l30
Italien/BRD, 1979, 70 min, Digital HD, I/e, Regie: Federico Fellini, Drehbuch: Federico Fellini, Brunello Rondi, mit: Balduin Baas, Clara Colosimo, Elizabeth Labi, Ronaldo Bonacch. Spielzeiten und Tickets:
In einer abbruchreifen Kirche hat sich ein Orchester zur Probe eingefunden. Während ein Fernsehteam Aufnahmen macht, proben die Musiker nicht nur die Noten, sondern auch den Aufstand. Der Dirigent wird zusehends weniger mit dem Chaos im Saal fertig. Als sich dann doch alle dem Maestro unterordnen, nutzt dieser seine neu gewonnene Macht schamlos aus – bis wie ein Deus ex machina die mächtige Betonbirne eines Abbruchbaggers die Kirchenmauer durchbricht und dem Durcheinander ein Ende bereitet. Im letzten Film, den Nino Rota gemeinsam mit Fellini realisierte, wird die Musik von selbst zum Thema: Der Verfall des Musikbetriebs gerät zum Zerrbild der modernen Gesellschaft
http://www.cinema-italiano.ch/cinema-italiano/ (2018)

From Carla
Domani 19 Maggio Italian cafè alle ore 21:00 Topic: il Genio di Leonardo Da Vinci

https://youtu.be/epUuCRzxfSA

item.title: 2021.03.12 Zoom Tasting Cognacs and Brandies
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Check your wine / liquor cabinet and join us! From 8 pm on Friday 12 March.

We had a good time tasting, Grhaam had provided some samples from his stock. But no-one was really impressed. Mixes were interesting, and orange cointreu pronounced the best drink.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Cointreau is the leading brand of triple sec, an orange flavored liqueur made from sweet and bitter orange peels. While Cointreau is not a cognac, its connections with cognac run deep. For starters, Cointreau is owned by the French spirits conglomerate Rémy Contreau, an entity that also owns Cognac House Rémy Martin. More importantly, triple sec, particularly Cointreau, seems to be the perfect flavored liqueur to compliment the rich complexities of Cognac.
For nearly a century, cognac lovers have mixed Cointreau with their cognac and a dash of lemon to create the Sidecar cocktail. Indeed, the orange flavors were also deemed a perfect match for cognac back in 1880 when Grand Marnier was created by Louis-Alexandre Marnier Lapostolle by blending premium cognac with distilled bitter orange.
https://www.cognac.com/blog/cointreau-and-cognac/

item.title: 2021.03.01 Newsletter March-April 2021
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Message from the President

We move with the times, adapting to reduced mobility and fears for our wellness and economic well-being. So we now have online parties and zoom discussion meetings, and lots of outdoor activities. Join in at any time – it is fun, motivating and mind-expanding.

We are losing our website provider, groupspaces, so we have created alternatives – a new Calendar, new mailing lists, and a Blog. We will continue to use the web domain www.icberne.ch though at this address, you will see a new website.

2021 is the year for our Club Biennial General Meeting. We hear reports on the past and the future of the club, we consider motions for change, and we elect a new Executive Committee. With your help, we can survive lockdowns to bring us into new modes of activity life with an invigorated membership.

Graham Tritt

PS: It is time to renew your membership for 2021
The Club has survived, while members come and go, and we need your support.

See our new blog: https://icberne.wordpress.com/

Newsletter March-April 2021Download

item.title: Newsletters
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
The Newsletter is the main communication channel of the International Club of Berne.

A paper version of the Newsletter is sent by post to each member household, and optionally a digital version by email.

If you are interested in the club, send us your postal address and we will send you newsletters for free for two months. Then we will ask you if you wish to join the club. For more information, see the Join page.

We include some of our Newsletters as blog posts.

item.title: 2020.12.01 November-December 2020 Newsletter
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Message from the President

Remember the days when we were on the telephone for hours? Or maybe writing letters? Do you recall telegrams or faxes? Shortwave radio for international news?

Now in the Internet age, letters are often replaced by emails (though writing letters is a great activity for the mind and spirit – we could well develop this habit again). And more recently, emails are being replaced by instant messages, and group mails are moving to WhatsApp.

Do you now keep in touch with relatives and friends using Skype? Because it’s good to talk and see faces at the same time. So we now have online meetings.

Do you keep in touch with friends and relatives using social media like Facebook? Do you use Xing or LinkedIn for business networking? Tell us about it…

So in Corona Time, the Club now weaves a path through outside activities, small group meetings, and online discussions. Join at any time and contribute – it is fun, motivating and mind-expanding.

Please check carefully page 7 and 8 for your own personal interests.
See the new groups we have made for you.

Graham Tritt

PS: If you are ill, or depressed, call someone, and join me and chat. If you would like to talk with just a few friends, I will get a conversation running. The Club has been an energizing resource in the past for members who have lost parents, partners and siblings!

PPS: It is time to renew your membership for the next year. The club has survived while members come and go, and we need your support

See the Newsletter November-December 2020

Newsletter November-December 2020Download

item.title: Newsletter for January-February 2021
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Message from the President 

The most unusual year of my life, perhaps yours too? Who could have predicted it? I know: numerous science fiction books, disaster films and planning scenarios. But on the way ,we have had an outbreak of disinformation, a culture of blaming, and a flood of conspiracy theories without historical parallel. Political realignments, economic recessions, wars and famines as usual, and then a general ignoring of climate change and its implications. What have we got to look forward to? 

In Corona Time, the Club now weaves a path through outside activities, small group meetings and online discussions. Join in at any time and contribute – it is fun, motivating and mind-expanding. 

Please check carefully the Activity Groups for your own personal interests (pages 7–9 and 12). We create groups when enough people are interested – for instance, there are new groups now for Russian, handcrafts and information technologies. The hiking and walking groups continue to be very active, and we also now have winter sports, including skating, skiing and other forms of snow activities.

Now 2021 is an election year for our Club and we can build a new committee with your help, to bring us into the new way of life with an invigorated membership and real, in-person meetings again.

Graham Tritt

PPS: It is time to renew your membership for the next year.
The Club has survived while members come and go,
and we need your support.

Newsletter January-February 2021Download

Calendar 2021


The Newsletter for January-February 2021 can be found here.

item.title: 2021.04.09 Lebanese Cuisine
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Dining – Lebanese Cuisine
When Friday, 9 April from 18:30
Where Zoom meeting
Contact Emelia (to register and discuss what and when to prepare)
Deadline Please register by Monday, 6 April

We will begin by having the participants (singly or in groups) introduce themselves and the menus, and then we can start cooking. Participants will, of course, have already prepared what they plan to cook, beginning at around 18:30. We can take our place “at the table” by 19:30.

Procedure of the evening:
1 If you plan to participate as a group, choose the number of your guests (according to safety covid-regulations).
2 Set your own menu (choose from the attached receipes), select your favourite wine.
3 Share the tasks among each other (who makes what).
4 We start Zoom meeting at 18:30 with introducing ourselves and our choice of menu.
5 Allow about 45 minutes for preparing and cooking.
6 We take our seats at the dining table at 19:30.

Suggestions of dishes:
- https://www.themediterraneandish.com/category/lebanese/
- https://verygoodrecipes.com/lebanese-recipes

Those who are not confident in their cooking can get a good takeaway meal at Rest. Domino in Schwanengasse. - suggestion from Graham

Suggestions of wines to go with the meal:

  • Tahuna Sauvignon blanc from Denner, CHF 6,95
  • Bojador vinho regional alentejano from Landi, CHF 8,95
  • Caravaggio Rosso from Aldi, CHF 9,95
  • Legón Premium D.O. Ribera del Duero from Denner with 50 % off, cost CHF 12,50
  • Yume Tre Autoctoni Vino Rosso d'Italia from Denner, CHF 28,50
  • Ixir 2013 grand reserve lebanese red wine) from Flaschenpost, CHF 33,90

This event is open to only ICB members. See the About page for information on the Club.

More books https://www.meetup.com/zurichbookclub/events/past/

How does a meeting run? From the discussion in October 2020
Marianne: Sophie’s Bookclub meeting from 6- 7: 30 pm. I think this is not enough time for in- depth discussion. Too short in my opinion. I think it is nice to have time at the start to say hello to everybody, have a cup of tea or coffee and a short exchange. Team spirit, a sense of community grows… Then the book discussion starts. .. It should last in my opinion at least until 8:00 pm.
What do other members think?
Mary: Really nicely said, Marianne. It is a chance for exchanging and listening to people we sort of know but otherwise all have different programs. I am not sure, is 6 OR 7 PM start what is meant. My preference is 7 til 9 or so.
Jacqui and Ulrike agreed
Graham: Yes for smalltalk and community building, we should have 2 hours. My preference is for 6 to 8 pm or a half hour later, as I play tennis at 9 pm. In September it will be dark at around 8 pm I think
Marianne: Perhaps, if you must leave to play tennis, we can stay longer and talk, exchange ideas and experiences and get to know eachother better.
From my experience, about 1.5 hours is as much as the average persons expects to stay, and a half hour extra is no problem for most of us. Most come to talk about the particular book, and few are impatient with the initial time socializing and talking in general about our current reading. There are many other frequent club events (see www.icberne.ch) where many member meet.
We should also allow for those who would like to take part but cannot get to the physical discussion. So we use the chat group, replacing the previous yahoo email group (which also had file archive

Most people will be "home alone" and perhaps testing out recipes. The zoom room will be open from early to late, and you can drop in for a quick chat at 6 or 7 pm before the main discussion at 8 pm. Have a glass of wine ready for toasting!

Friday, 29 Jan – Whisky Tasting (celebration of Burns eveing possibly also with poetry and the cooking should be leek soup and haggis)

Friday, 5 February - New Zealand party

It is New Zealand's national day, see www.waitangi.org.nz, celebrating the treaty between Maori tribal chiefs and the British government in 1840. It starts locally on 5 February at 5 am with a dawn and flag-raising ceremony, and continues all day. New Zealand is 12 hours ahead of CET so we will occasionally tune in our Zoom to see the entertainment as it is going on.

item.dc:creator: bernagora

ICB Website Launch Zoom Meeting - invitation sent from the old website.

Friday March 26 from 20:00 to 21:45 PM. ZOOM PARTY. The link will be given on request. Drop in at any time and say hallo and stay as long as you like.

The online meeting is easiest to use if you have installed Zoom.us. But if not, you can still take part, using your browser on PC or pad or smartphone. You can test your connection from 7:45 PM

Bring a drink and toast with us. And give in your suggestions!

We announce the new website www.icberne.org

We will have (1) a demonstration overview of the website at 20:30 for 10 minutes, and (2) a demonstration of its blog system at 21:00. It's not simple, so please learn and experiment! We would like all to be able to post events on the blog.

This will probably be the last club email that you receive through the "groupspaces" site which hosts us. We are not sure yet how our email communications will continue. You should subscribe to the new WordPress site, and follow posts of activities that interest you. If you have not received our March-April newsletter, contact us. You may still have to pay the 2021 subscription (CHF 50/60)

Other events (see pages 10-11 of the Newsletter):

  • This week we had good Italian and German conversation cafés.
  • The city visit to Geneva is rescheduled to 8 May. There were 3 members on a great visit to Sion last month with CHTOUR.ch
  • Summertime starts on March 28, you get an extra hour of the day!Monday evening zoom discussion meetings: on 29 March on politics, on 5 April world health
  • Winter sports in Schwarzsee on Saturday 3 April, if conditions are good
  • Fools Day is April 1, you lose the hour again!

item.title: 2021.04.03 Winter Sports at the Schwarzsee
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Winter Sports Day at the Schwarzsee

When: Sundays, 3 January, 28 February, 3 April

Where: Berne train station Treffpunkt, or from short-term parking (share autos, CHF 15)

We take the train at about 10.00 from Berne to Fribourg, connecting with a bus to Schwarzsee, where we meet between 12:00–13:00 at Restaurant Gypsera, next to the lake and a parking area next to the ski lifts. We may share rides, expenses CHF 10-15 pp.

Schwarzsee is great for winter sports of all kinds. If frozen, the lake may be open for walking and skating. A cross-country ski trail winds around the lake. Sledgers and ski learners can use the hill near the Gypsera, while skiers take the chairlifts upwards (see www.schwarzsee.ch).

Between 16:00 and 17:00, we meet in the Hostellerie overlooking the lake (www.hostellerieamschwarzsee.ch) for a snack. At the Hostellerie, equipment can be rented, and there is a wellness area.

You may be able to visit the spectacular Ice Palace (see www.eispalaeste.ch)

item.title: 2020 Tours with CHTOUR
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
From www.chtour.ch

18. Januar 2020 Wir besuchen die höchstgelegene Stadt der Schweiz im Winter – La Chaux-de-Fonds, UNESCO-Weltkulturgut. Bei einer Führung des Tourismusbüros entdecken wir die Innenräume der Stadt im lokalen Jugendstil (“style sapin”). Details hier


21. März 2020 Speziell kulturell: Basel (Tagesausflug). Am  Morgen sind wir in der Altstadt unterwegs und fragen uns, was Erasmus von Rotterdam in Basel gesucht und gefunden hat. Am Nachmittag entdecken wir Kleinbasel. Die Details finden Sie hier


18. April 2020 Die andere Zähringerstadt. Vormittags Stadtrundgang in Fribourg, nachmittags Besuch des Klosters Hauterive (Tagesausflug). Die Details finden Sie hier ab Kalenderwoche 8 (Mitte Februar).

2.- 10. Mai 2020 Von Sigmaringen nach Stuttgart. Wir haben in der Schule Deutsch gelernt, aber verstehen wir die Deutschen? Wir versuchen es und beginnen in Württemberg. Auf landschaftlich ansprechenden Bahnstrecken erreichen wir zwei Schlösser der Hohenzollern-Dynastie, besuchen das protestantische Tübingen und das katholische Rottenburg, entdecken die Metropole Stuttgart mit ihren Museen und Bauprojekten (Weissenhofsiedlung von 1927, Stuttgart 21), das barocke Residenzschloss Ludwigsburg samt seinen Gärten sowie die Schillerstadt Marbach am Neckar, in der sich auch das deutsche Literaturmuseum der Moderne befindet. Nicht zufällig findet die Reise während der Spargelsaison statt. Das genaue Programm finden Sie hier spätestens Ende Januar.

20. Juni 2020 Was hat Bern im Jura verloren? Ein Tag im neusten Kanton der Schweiz und in der Kantonshauptstadt Delémont (Delsberg), an dem es auch um die Geschichte des Jurakonflikts geht. Genaue Angaben zum Programm finden sie hier spätestens Mitte April.

15. August 2020 Emmental. Am Vormittag Stadtrundgang in Burgdorf, am Nachmittag Besuch des Gotthelf-Museums in Lützelflüh (Tagesausflug). Details hier spätestens Mitte Mai.

5. – 13. September  2020 Kathedralen und Champagner. Auf dieser Reise besuchen wir gotische Kathedralen in der Champagne und der Picardie. Hier wurde das Frankenreich vor über 1500 Jahren christlich, hier ist die Gotik entstanden. Die meisten besuchten Städte liegen abseits des Massentourismus. Details hier

3.-11. Oktober 2020 Von Augsburg nach Verona. Kultur an der jahrtausendealten Verbindung von Deutschland nach Italien. Bahnfahrten durch das Gebirge auf der Mittenwaldbahn und über den Brenner. Aufenthalte in Augsburg, Füssen (Besuch des UNESCO-Weltkulturguts Wieskirche), Innsbruck (Tirol), Bozen (Südtirol), Trient (Planungsort der Gegenreformation) und schliesslich Verona (“Welschbern”). Das genaue Programm finden Sie hier spätestens Ende Juni.

17. Oktober 2020 oder 21. November 2020: Ziel und Thema des Ausflugs legen wir im Lauf des Jahres fest.

6.-13. Februar 2021 Städte der Lombardei – Monza, Bergamo, Brescia, Mantova, Cremona

item.title: 2020.07.04 Tour: Culture in the Emmental
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
chtour.ch  Excursions and trips with culture
Corona virus: we comply with hygiene and distance rules!

Burgdorf und Lützelflüh: Culture in the Emmental
Day trip 4. Juli 2020

Burgdorf becomes a cultural center with the reopening of Burgdorf Castle in June 2020. In addition to the castle with its knight's hall and its collections on Pestalozzi and city and industrial history, there are two other museums worth seeing: the museum of the painter Franz Gertsch and the collection of the metal artist Bernhard Luginbühl in the old slaughterhouse (current exhibition: Alfred and Sabina Hofkunst).

The small town in the lower part of the Emmental was founded by the Zähringer family in the last third of the 12th century, around the same time as Bern. At the beginning of the 1830s, the replacement of patrician rule in the canton of Bern was planned in Burgdorf.

After a one-hour city tour with a culture-loving woman fro Burgdorf, there is enough time for individual visits to the three museums and for lunch.

In the early afternoon, we take the train to Lützelflüh in twelve minutes. It's about literature. Albert Bitzius, who later became Jeremias Gotthelfannah, is compared to Dostoevsky and other classics. After our introduction, which is mainly about his first book "Bauernspiegel", there is time for an individual visit to the Gotthelf Center, which is housed in the rooms in which Gotthelf lived with his family at the time.

Meeting point: Burgdorf station at 08.55 (Bern from 08.38 with the Inter-Regio towards Zurich).

The cost of the tour is CHF 10, free for children. Entry to museums and exhibitions is not included. Information: 076 303 09 29. We appreciate it if you register by email at chtour@chtour.ch

item.title: 2019.04.06 Emmental Tour
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Four ICB members enjoyed the Trachselwald hike. Lots of photos may be added later

From Michael Tschanz of www.chtour.ch

I would be ready to do a special tour in English in Bern, similar to the introductory tour we did for chtour.ch on 2 March, where we explained how Berne managed to become powerful in spite of being founded at a very late moment in history, and how the construction of the Münster (not really a cathedral, because there was no bishop) was linked to the territorial expansion of the Bernese state. Because we had mostly Bernese with us at that occasion, it was important for me to show them what they believed to know but didn't really look at - the medieval stained glass windows, what they show, how they can be understood within their time.

Reports of the walks are on www.chtour.ch/blog/

6. April,  Geschichte und Literatur in und um Trachselwald – Bern ab 09.50 mit der Bahn. Themen sind die Täufer, die Bauernkriege, die Schriftsteller Jeremias Gotthelf und Carl Albert Loosli. Tagesausflug.

    Hier gibt’s die Details dazu.  https://www.chtour.ch/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Trachselwald06Apr2019.pdf

4. Mai, spiritueller Maibummel im Luzernbiet. Wir entdecken die Stadt Sursee und die barocken Kirchen und Wallfahrtskapellen aus der Zeit der Gegenreformation in den Gemeinden Buttisholz und Ruswil. Gehzeit etwa zwei Stunden.

Details hier: http://www.chtour.ch/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Surseee-Buttisholz-St-Ottilien-Ruswil-4Mai2019.pdf

1. Juni, ins Waadtland zu Jacques Chessex. Wir reisen nach Moudon und Ropraz und beschäftigen uns mit dem preisgekrönten Schriftsteller Jacques Chessex, der vor zehn Jahren im Zorn gestorben ist.
Details hier: http://www.chtour.ch/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Moudon-Ropraz-1Jun2019.pdf


6. Juli, Besançon – langsam nach Frankreich. Nicht mit dem TGV, sondern in einem Schienenbus mit Dieselmotor fahren wir in die Hauptstadt der Franche-Comté. Zwei kurze Rundgänge. Früh aufstehen – Bern ab 06.53. Details hier.

3. August, die frühen Habsburger. Wanderung Brugg-Altenburg-Habsburg-Königsfelden. Wir gehen zu den Ursprungsorten der Habsburgerdynastie. Höhepunkt des Tages ist die Besichtigung der ehemaligen Klosterkirche Königsfelden mit ihren mittelalterlichen Glasfenstern. Details in Vorbereitung.

7. September, Solothurn. Rundgang durch das Zentrum,  Besuch eines ehemaligen Landsitzes, Wanderung durch die Verena-Schlucht. Söldnertum und barocke Pracht, Adel und Ambassadoren. Details in Vorbereitung.

5. Oktober mit Friedrich Dürrenmatt am Bielersee und in Neuenburg (Neuchâtel). Richter, Henker und mehr. Details in Vorbereitung.

2. November Ursprünge des Christentums im Gebiet der heutigen Schweiz. In Avenches sehen wir die wohl ältesten christlichen Gegenstände in der Schweiz. Dann besuchen wir das im Jahre 515 gegründete Kloster St. Maurice und seinen Klosterschatz. Und schliesslich besuchen wir etwas ausserhalb des Ortes eine Wallfahrtskapelle, die an die Hinrichtung der legendären Thebäischen Legion erinnert. Details in Vorbereitung.

7. Dezember, Weihnachtsmarkt Montbéliard. Die Stadt (deutsch Mömpelgard) war bis zur französischen Revolution württembergisch und protestantisch. Stadtführung, Besichtigung des Schlosses und des protestantischen «Temple». Zeit, um das Städtchen und den Weihnachtsmarkt selbst zu entdecken. Fahrt via Delle und Belfort (die Bahnlinie war von 1993 bis 2018 geschlossen).

item.title: 2019 Cultural Tours with CHtour
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
7. September, Solothurn. Rundgang durch das Zentrum,  Besuch eines ehemaligen Landsitzes, Wanderung durch die Verena-Schlucht. Söldnertum und barocke Pracht, Adel und Ambassadoren. 5 ICB members attended in a group of 12

5. Oktober mit Friedrich Dürrenmatt am Bielersee und in Neuenburg (Neuchâtel). Richter, Henker und mehr. Details in Vorbereitung. Graham attended in a group of 10

2. November Ursprünge des Christentums im Gebiet der heutigen Schweiz. In Avenches sehen wir die wohl ältesten christlichen Gegenstände in der Schweiz. Dann besuchen wir das im Jahre 515 gegründete Kloster St. Maurice und seinen Klosterschatz. Und schliesslich besuchen wir etwas ausserhalb des Ortes eine Wallfahrtskapelle, die an die Hinrichtung der legendären Thebäischen Legion erinnert. Details in Vorbereitung. 2 ICB members attended but only as far as Avenches

Ursprungsorte des Christentums in der Schweiz

Tagesausflug nach Avenches und Saint-Maurice, 7. September 2019

Die Schweizer haben das Christentum nicht erfunden. Aber es gibt Orte, an denen das Christentum auf dem Gebiet der heutigen Schweiz erstmals auftaucht. Zwei dieser Ursprungsorte besuchen wir.

In Avenches haben wir Zeit für einen Bummel durch die Altstadt. Anschliessend schlagen wir vor, im römischen Museum die frühesten Gegenstände, die in der Schweiz auf die neue Religion hinweisen, zu betrachten. Es sind Gläser aus dem 4. Jahrhundert, die als Grabbeigabendienten.

Anschliessend geht es langsam mit dem Zug nach Moudon, mit dem Bahnersatzbus nach Palézieux und von dort auf einer eher unbekannten Bahnlinie durch die Weinberge direkt nach Vevey (also ohne Umwegüber Lausanne).

Nach einem halbstündigen Aufenthalt, der eine kurze Verpflegung erlaubt, geht die Reise weiter nach Saint-Maurice, wo wir das seit 515 bestehende Kloster, die Ausgrabungen und den reichen Klosterschatz mit Werken frühchristlicher Kunst besuchen, der nach einer Ausstellung im Louvre neu präsentiert wird.

Bei Acaunum, heute Saint-Maurice d’Agaune, wurde gemäss der Überlieferung um das Jahr 300 die Thebäische Legion hingerichtet, römische Soldaten aus Theben angeführt vom Heiligen Mauritius.

Neben Mauritius wurden und werden verschiedene Märtyrer aus Theben verehrt, und zwar Urs (in Solothurn), Verena (in Zurzach), Felix und Regula (in Zürich), Solutor, Octavius und Adventor (in Turin), Victor (in Solothurn, Genfund Marseille). In der Kapellein Vérolliez bei Saint-Maurice, die am angeblichen Ort des Massakers errichtet wurde, ist es trotzdem sehr still.

Treffpunkt: Bahnhof Avenches um 09.30 Uhr
(Bern ab 08.34 mit der S-Bahn 52, Richtung Kerzers).
Am besten für die Hinfahrt eine Fahrkarte via Kerzers, Moudon und Chexbres nach St-Maurice lösen.

Gehzeitvom Kloster Saint-Maurice zur Kapelle von Vérolliez eine knappe halbe Stunde.

Der Kostenbeitrag für die Führung beträgt 10 CHF, für Kinder gratis. Zusätzlich kostet der Eintritt zu den Ausgrabungen und zum Klosterschatz in Saint-Maurice 15 Franken pro Person.

Auskunft: 076 303 09 29. Wir schätzen es, wenn Sie sich per Mail anmelden: chtour@chtour.ch.

https://www.chtour.ch/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Avenches-Saint-Maurice.pdf

item.title: 2021.03.28 Gabelbach Walk
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Attendance was limited to members of the Toastmsters club, because we were walking, reciting, giving speeches, and playing games. But 6 ICB members are Toastmasters, there is interclub cooperation.

We started at Westside (the Berne Brunnen railway station) and walked west to the creek called Gabelbach.

We continued along the Gabelback river down towards lake Wohlen.

A winding river, lots of BBQ, sport and play areas, even an aquaduct!

Total distance abot 10 km easy walk. Not suitable for baby strollers.

item.title: Tasting
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
We have started new activities in the club, which will appeal to a lot of us. The general term is tasting - because we do not consider ourselves generally as gourmets or experts, but just people who like sensations!

First and regularly we have wine-tasting events, and occasionally whisky and beer tasting events, brandies and grappas and cocktails too!

We also plan cheese, cigar, and tea-tasting!

Then we also have cooking and cuisine evenings and brunches and a monthly TGIF meeting for end of week drinks or a meal.

Most of the Tasting activities events are restricted to International Club members only (plus friends of the hosts). They are normally not open for non-members.

item.title: 2014.09.06 Cooking Group 2012/2013
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
This group started in November 2012 with Italian cuisine. The event was very successful and the demand for the participation has been so great that we had to limit attendance and have a waiting list.  

The group has held events with cuisines from Italy, Malaysia, Indonesia, Estonia, Rumania, India and the Philippines.

The events were not continued after September 2013 due to lack of hosts and leaders.

- This report from Nazanin and Emeliana.

Events have restarted in 2019. Attendance is limited to ICB members and friends of the host. Wine tastings have continued.

- This addition from Graham.

item.title: 2021.04.25 Panorama Bridge walk - Sigriswil
item.dc:creator: icbrelling
item.content:encoded:
Arriving at ca. 11:00 - Graham, Vernon, Hokan and Yvette. Graham and Hokan ventured over the bridge to check the bridge out. A 180 meter drop to the bottom. Yvette walked down and up with her two dogs.

Then we all went down to the Gunten lakeside access near the Park hotel to have lunch. The whole lake area was full with Sunday drivers so a walk along the lake towards Beatenbucht was soon abandoned because of noise and traffic beside the road. After a beer and coffee from the restaurant at the lake Gunten Hokan and Vernon then walked from Oberhofen to Thun, finishing the day with a great meal beside the river.

item.title: 2021-10-03 Verena
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
The leisurely stroll from the centre of Solothurn to the entrance of Verena Gorge takes about 30 minutes. A well-managed and easy trail then leads through the wild and romantic gorge, always along the babbling brook until it reaches the hermitage.

The hermitage, which is named after St. Verena and dates back to the 15th century, includes a hermit’s dwelling and two chapels. One of the two chapels is among the oldest buildings in Solothurn. According to a centuries-old custom, the hermitage continues to be maintained by a real hermit. Verena Gorge is especially beautiful during wintertime.

item.title: Newsletters 2022
item.dc:creator: ausfrog
item.content:encoded:
Extracts from the 2022 Newsletters

NL20221112E

The warm sun has now been replaced by wonderful autumn colours, though admittedly, it’s now a bit harder getting up mornings in the dark.

Our Club events are gradually moving indoors. The Autumn Party at the Murrihuus in October was well attended by members and friends, and the Committee is now actively planning its Christmas party.

In the meantime, we will be trying out new TGIF venues, and with the weather turning colder, our walks and hikes will decrease in length and altitude. Our language cafés will continue well into December, though our winter sports will probably have to wait for sufficient snow in the new year.

Graham and the team are not short of new ideas for activities, and with the various WhatsApp groups now in place, these activities can be organized more spontaneously. And as always, we welcome any input from you, the members.

Lastly, on the behalf of the Club, I wish to extend a warm welcome to our new members listed on page 5. I am leaving this month on a long-awaited trip to Australia to spend the end of year with family. Enjoy the coming holidays and I wish you all a marvellous 2023.

January/February 2002

item.title: Panoramic easy hike of the Gübertal
item.dc:creator: bernagora
item.content:encoded:
Organised by Mini Chaperon Rouge

This spontaneous hike takes advantage of a break from the rain on Saturday morning 😉without going too far from Berne. It offers green fields, big old farms and hopefully views of the Gantrisch and Bernese Alps.

We will start from the Kehrsatz station and finish in Kaufdorf. It is a 14 kms walk with a bit an ascent at the beginning and a short steep descent after Oberfeld.

For those who prefer a shorter walk, an intersection allows a descent to Belp through the forest, saving around 6-7 kms.

A couple of landmarks: the Teufelstein (Rock of the Devil) thrown there by the Aar glacier 20,000 years ago and a sign reminder of 2 monks who lived in the Pfaffenloch, a cave, 900 years ago.

Bring good walking shoes, a packed lunch, walking poles if you want but do not forget a raincoat and umbrella in case and a lot of good humour.

We may find a place close to the station in Kaufdorf for a drink and a chat at the end or just take the train together to Belp to catch the air show and/or have a drink.

From https://www.meetup.com/meetup-bern/events/293463120/
